src/program_1/main.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*! \file
00002  *      \brief The second user program -
00003  *             in a neverending loop, sends a message to process 0 and waits
00004  *             for a reply. When the test case runs, there will be two
00005  *             instances of this program running.
00006  */
00007 
00008 #include <scwrapper.h>
00009 
00010 /* Define the debug messages to print on the console.
00011    Since we don't know until run-time which process id this process has,
00012    we defined them here and then modify the process number (the "n") later. */
00013 
00014 char findport_process_failed[]  = "process n: findport on my own port failed\n";
00015 char findport_process0_failed[] = "process n: findport for process 0 failed\n";
00016 char sending_ping[]                 = "process n: sending ping\n";
00017 char send_failed[]                          = "process n: send failed\n";
00018 char recv_failed[]                          = "process n: receive failed\n";
00019 char recvd_pong[]                           = "process n: received pong\n";
00020 char test_failed[]                          = "process n: message test failed\n";
00021 
00022 void 
00023 main(int argc, char* argv[])
00024 {
00025  long send_port, recv_port;
00026  long my_pid;
00027  char pidchar;
00028  
00029  my_pid = getpid();
00030 
00031  if (my_pid<0)
00032  {
00033   prints("Can not get my PID!");
00034   debugger();
00035  }
00036 
00037  /* Setup the strings, replacing "n" with the actual process identity. */
00038 
00039  /* Convert my_pid to a character. */
00040  pidchar = '0' + (char) my_pid;
00041 
00042  /* And insert on the 9th place in the char arrays. */
00043  findport_process_failed[8]     = pidchar;
00044  findport_process0_failed[8]    = pidchar;
00045  sending_ping[8]                                = pidchar;
00046  send_failed[8]                                 = pidchar;
00047  recv_failed[8]                                 = pidchar;
00048  recvd_pong[8]                                  = pidchar;
00049  test_failed[8]                                 = pidchar;
00050 
00051  /* Get the port index for our own port 0. */ 
00052  recv_port=findport(0,my_pid);
00053  if (recv_port < 0)
00054  {
00055   prints(findport_process_failed);
00056   debugger();
00057  }
00058 
00059  /* Get the port index for process 0's port 0. */
00060  send_port=findport(0,0);
00061  if (send_port < 0)
00062  {
00063   prints(findport_process0_failed);
00064   debugger();
00065  }
00066 
00067  /* Go into an infinite loop, sending messages and waiting for replies. */
00068  while(1)
00069  {
00070   struct message msg;
00071   unsigned long  sender, type;
00072 
00073   msg.quad_0=0;
00074   msg.quad_1=1;
00075   msg.quad_2=2;
00076   msg.quad_3=3;
00077   msg.quad_4=4;
00078   msg.quad_5=5;
00079   msg.quad_6=6;
00080   msg.quad_7=7;
00081 
00082   prints(sending_ping);
00083 
00084   if (ALL_OK != send(send_port, &msg))
00085   {
00086    prints(send_failed);
00087    debugger();
00088   }
00089 
00090   if ((ALL_OK != receive(recv_port, &msg, &sender, &type)) ||
00091       (SYSCALL_MSG_SHORT != type) ||
00092       (0 != sender))
00093   {
00094    prints(recv_failed);
00095    debugger();
00096   }
00097 
00098   /* Test message validity. */
00099   if ((7 != msg.quad_0) ||
00100       (6 != msg.quad_1) ||
00101       (5 != msg.quad_2) ||
00102       (4 != msg.quad_3) ||
00103       (3 != msg.quad_4) ||
00104       (2 != msg.quad_5) ||
00105       (1 != msg.quad_6) ||
00106       (0 != msg.quad_7))
00107   {
00108    prints(test_failed);
00109    debugger();
00110   }
00111 
00112   prints(recvd_pong);
00113 
00114   debugger();
00115  }
00116 }
